author: madeof_tin7509
content:
To be blunt, the social cost for burning Eth in the deposit contract because of malformed signatures is really high. I am not in a position to tell the Eth2 team when to launch, nor when it is ready to launch phase 0, so i'm doing my best the situation as it is. In an ideal world a lot of these things wouldn't be a problem.

Also, Setting dates is a practical way to move things along. If we don't push EIPs then we run into the risk of them never reaching "ready".  Feedback like yours Axic is appreciated and needed. Talking about timeline is a good catalyst for uncovering the pieces that aren't ready and so they can be addressed.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: I am open to feedback on how to manage this and other EIP things better.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: So thoughts are appreciated

author: madeof_tin7509
content: I'd like to strike a balance between, "hard" deadlines and "soft" leaving things undone that could be. Perhaps i'm too far in either direction.

author: Deleted User
content: I think there are many ways of screening the deposits for malformed signatures. Introducing a not well tested change in Eth1x just for that might be one of the less efficient options. It seems to me that what happened in this occasion was that we had generalised curve precompiles, which still needs a lot of work, but can be done. Then there was a desire to do "at least something", and that "something would be BLS curve, because it is used in Eth2.0 somehow". And then there was a solution looking for a problem, and hence the "chicken and egg problem", IMO

author: djrtwo
content:
A few more points for the value here:
- That bls curve is being adopted by many projects so cross compatibility is a win
- opens up writing an eth2 light client in solidity which would allow used of eth2 data layer before a full merge. Could be big win for rollups, etc
- maker wants to use aggregate sig verification for oracles. Aggregate verification (a feature of bls) of an increasingly common signature type will likely be a win in many applications

author: djrtwo
content:
Agree that there are other methods of verifying sigs before sending 32 eth into oblivion. 
That said, we've seen many people mess this up alreasy on test nets. Working on tools to shore it it up without the eip and hopefully can prevent most issues before it hits the evm. Its a nice to have but will probably save more than one person some money and pain
